results.title: Grandma Jessie
results.brief_description: In this very personal story, Stephanie King pays tribute to her Grandma Jessie and reflects on the influence her upbringing by her grandmother has had on her own education and outlook.

results.title: The Best life
results.creator_credit: Keifer Yu, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Keifer Yu takes us beyond the tourist attractions of Broome, Western Australia, to the cultures therein. Yu focuses on the Indigenous and Chinese cultures of which he is a part. He considers how the differing cultures have enriched his life and how they blend in together in this unique community.

results.title: Food gathering
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Indians of the Orinoco: the Makiritare”.
Records how the Waika and Makiritare Indians of South America gather some of their food from the jungle. Includes catching of snakes, fish and worms and their preparation for eating and the collection of leaves which are beaten and mashed and used ingeniously to catch fish. Suitable for middle and upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Blowgun
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Indians of the Orinoco: the Makiritare”.
Explains that in a single day a Makiritare craftsman tailors a blowgun with precision fittings that will last for years. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.

results.title: Manioc bread
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Indians of the Orinoco: the Makiritare”.
Shows Makiritare women making bread from manioc roots. First they remove the poison by squeezing the shredded roots in enormous basket-tubes. From the flour they make yucca or cassava bread, a dietary staple. The bread is toasted on a flat piece of iron and tossed onto a roof to dry. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Hermann Schlenker, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation

results.title: Jungle farming
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Indians of the Orinoco: the Makiritare”.
Describes the cooperative work involved in jungle farming of the Makiritare Indians. Explains that, after the men use the slash and burn technique to clear the jungle away, the women simultaneously harvest and plant manioc roots, pineapples, chillipeppers, bananas and plantations. Living near the equator they can farm all the year round. Suitable for upper primary and lower secondary levels.
results.description:

results.title: Village life
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Indians of the Orinoco: the Makiritare”.
Introduces the variety of activities in the Makiritare Indian village of Kononama (South America). Women spin cotton, look after babies and chickens, and bathe in the river, while the children draw, wrestle and throw spears. Men weave baskets from sisal for squeezing the poison out of manloc roots and make jewellery for a dance.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Hermann Schlenker, Julien Bryan and International Film Foundation

results.title: Woodwinds and dance
results.creator_credit: Hermann Schlenker and International Film Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Indians of the Orinoco: the Makiritare”.
One of a series of films recording the various aspects of daily life among the remote tribes of Indians in the South American jungles. Using large pieces of bamboo, two young men make bassoon like instruments, which are used in a village dance.

results.title: A Boy called "Rabbit"
results.creator_credit: Ken Cumming, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
results.brief_description: Ken Cumming’s dearest memory of the time he served in Vietnam was a young boy by the name of “Rabbit”. While “Rabbit” couldn’t speak English, he was popular with the Australian soldiers for his fast running and bravery.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ken Cumming, ACMI Digital Storytelling and ACMI
